headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- the typical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with the SEC. This presentati
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- the typical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with the SEC. This presentation is being webcast in our earnings release, statistical summaries and slide for this presentation are available on our website at tecoenergy.com. 
This presentation will be available for replay through the website approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of our presentation and will be available for 30 days. 
In the course of our remarks today, we will be making forward-looking statements about our expectations for 2015 results. There are a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we'll discuss today. For a more complete discussion of these factors, we refer you to the risk factor discussion in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2014. 
In the course of today's presentation, we will be using non-GAAP results. There is a reconciliation between these non-GAAP measures in the closest GAAP measure in the appendix to today's presentation. 
The host for our call today is Sandy Callahan, TECO Energy's Chief Financial Officer. Also with us today is John Ramil, TECO Energy's Chief Executive Officer. I'll first turn it over to John for some opening remarks.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall on the afternoon of July 16, in response to the story that appeared on Sparks spread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that w
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall on the afternoon of July 16, in response to the story that appeared on Sparks spread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that we have retained Morgan Stanley to advise on this matter. At that time, we stated the exploration was preliminary nature, and we would not update the process or have any additional announcements regarding the matter unless or until we were to enter into a binding definitive agreement with respect to a sale. Today, we have now additional comments to make on this matter and we'll not be addressing this during the question-and-answer session at the end of Sandy's prepared remarks. 
As you saw in our earnings release this morning, due to ongoing negotiations for the sale of TECO Coal and an expected adjustment to the value of that business based on potential sales prices, we're reporting results from continuing operations only this morning. We do not expect individual operating company results we are reporting today to change as a result of any evaluation adjustments that we make in our discontinued operations. 
Now I'll turn it over to Sandy to cover the financial results for continuing operations. Sandy?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share compared with $0.28 last y
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share compared with $0.28 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $61.5 million in 2015 and includes $400,000 of charges related to the New Mexico Gas integration. Results in the quarter reflected close to breakeven results in New Mexico Gas and the full impact of the 16.7 million shares we issued in July last year in connection with that acquisition. That share impact diluted earnings about $0.02 in the quarter. 
For the first 6 months of the year, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $126.3 million, or $0.54 per share, compared with $0.51 last year. Net income from continuing operations for the 6 months was $125.3 million, compared with $110.7 million last year. Both years include cost associated with the New Mexico Gas acquisition, $1 million of integration costs in 2015 and $4.7 million of acquisition cost in 2014. 
Tampa Electric recorded higher net income in the second quarter, reflecting customer growth at a strong 1.8% and hot weather in April and May. We also had the second quarter effect of the base revenue increase that became effective November 1 of last year per Tampa Electric 2013 regulatory stipulation. 
With strong customer growth and better weather resulted in second quarter energy sales that was 6.6% higher than last year. 
AFUDC also increased this quarter, with higher investment balances in the Polk conversion project and other qualified projects. 
Second quarter weather was a real positive. April and May were much hotter than normal, which boosted Tampa Electric Energy sales but hurt Peoples Gas slightly at the tail end of the heating season. Hot weather in April have the air conditioners running early in the season, driving energy sales up but not at the same magnitude that the cooling degree days were up. With the lower humidity and cooler nights, the high daytime temperatures we saw in April don't generate the same energy sales volumes as they would in the continuously hot and humid summer months when air conditioners stays around 24/7. 
Peoples Gas has seen quarter after quarter of accelerated customer growth. And the second quarter continued this trend, customer growth of 2.2%. Growth was strongest in the Southwest Florida market that has been the most impacted in the economic downturn, as well as the Northeast Florida and Jacksonville areas. We saw lower therm sales to residential and commercial customers due to warm April weather at the end of the heating season. But higher therms transported for power generation customers and higher system sales due to increased coal-to-gas switching as well as new generating facilities common online. 
On the expense side, O&M was lower than last year despite higher employee-related costs. 
The already strong local economy was enhanced this quarter by tourists enjoying the spring weather and the Tampa Bay Lightning's run to the Stanley Cup Finals. Indicative of this, hotels bed tax collections in the Tampa area were at record levels this quarter. And for the 9 months ended June 2015, were more than 15% higher than they were in 2014. 
Although the hockey fans here on the run with me this morning did not like the ultimate outcome, we did appreciate all of the Detroit, Montréal, New York and Chicago fans who visited Tampa this spring. 
New Mexico Gas Company achieved close to breakeven results in the second quarter and that's the quarter that typically produces a moderate loss. This outcome reflects the benefits of O&M improvement from integration synergies being realized and customer growth that reached 0.7% [ph] in the quarter. 
The other net segment, what we used to refer to as, had a higher net cost in the second quarter compared to last year as we expected. This was driven by interest expense of the intermediate parent of New Mexico Gas Company; and tax expense related to long-term incentive compensation shares that vested below target level. The impact of no longer allocating interest expense to TECO Coal following its classification as a discontinued operations, was offset by lower interest expense from our refinancing in the second quarter. 
The Florida economy continues to be a good story. Statewide, unemployment at the end of the second quarter was 5.5%, an improvement over [ph] 4% [ph] from a year ago. At the same time, the state has added more than 266,000 new jobs over the past year, with the largest number of new jobs occurring in trade transport and utilities, business services and education and health services. The biggest percentage gain again this quarter occurred in the construction sector, with the 6% employment gain. 
Hillsborough County, Tampa Electric's primary service territory, once again outpaced the state and U.S. level, with unemployment down to 5.2%, almost a full percent below where it was a year ago. Over the past year, the Tampa's St. Petersburg area added 33,000 jobs, with the largest gains in leisure and hospitality, followed by education and health services. 
The unemployment rate in New Mexico was 6.4% in June, an improvement of 0.4% [ph] over a year ago. Not as dramatic as the improvements in Florida and the U.S, but, of course, the unemployment rate in New Mexico never came close to the peak level that we saw in Florida and nationally. 
Net job growth in New Mexico was 11,000 over the past year. A number impacted by some job losses in the oil and gas industry are the result of the recent weakness in energy prices. The largest gains in New Mexico's year-over-year job growth came in the education and health services, local government and professional and business services categories. 
Taxable sales, both in Florida and in Hillsborough County, continued to grow with a strong pace that was seen pretty consistently now over the last 4 years. Reflective of the strong tourist season, if you look at the graph in the appendix, you can see a very strong uptick in April of this year. 
On the housing front, the good story in Florida continues, with more than 5,500 new single-family building permits issued in Tampa Electric service territory over the past 12 months; and existing homes considering to sell at a very strong pace. 
The June Case-Shiller report shows that selling prices in the Tampa market increased 6.4% year-over-year, which doesn't seem to have dampened sales and the housing inventory remained at a healthy level of less than 4 months. 
The New Mexico housing market has posted gains as well. In Albuquerque, the state's largest metro area, existing home resales have trended up steadily over the past year. There was a very strong acceleration in the past several months, including a 33% year-over-year increase in June. Selling prices have also trended up and the inventory of homes available for resale is currently about 5 months. You can see all of these trends on the graph in the appendix. 
Our assumptions around guidance that we've provided previously remain unchanged. We're maintaining our previously provided guidance for 2015 earnings per share from continuing operations in a range of $1.08 to $1.11, excluding non-GAAP charges or gains. As a regulated utility company, weather is the biggest variable in our outlook, and we assume normal weather for all of our companies for the remainder of the year. That said, weather is other than normal, our operating companies have typically been very successful responding to weather variation within a reasonably normal range. 
This slide is another graphical reminder that our quarterly earnings pattern will look different with New Mexico Gas Company in our business mix. I've shown the slide previously that illustrated the New Mexico has a very seasonal earnings pattern, with very strong earnings in the cold-weather first and fourth quarters, while the warmer second and third quarters typically produced losses. That's a fairly normal pattern for a gas distribution system with significant residential heating load. So as you can see in the pro forma illustrations here, we expect to see quarterly results meaningfully higher in the first and fourth quarters and somewhat lower than in the second and third quarters than they've been in the past. That actually results in less quarterly variation through the year than we've seen in the past as the New Mexico and Florida earnings patterns are quite complementary. 
Biggest completion of our Polk conversion project is a very important component of our 2017 outlook. I'll again provide a brief status on the construction activities you've seen here. In short, the project is on schedule and it's on budget. This has proven conventional technology and the project scope is smaller than the Bayside conversion project that we successfully completed in the 2003, 2004 time frame. 
This picture shows the progress we're making installing the heat recovery steam generators. This second picture gives you some idea of the size and scope of this $700 million project. You can see the fourth combustion turbine, 2 on either side of the steam turbine island that's located in the center of the picture. 
We will complete our reporting of second quarter results on or before August 7, when we will report full GAAP results including discontinued operations. 
Next Thursday, we will be ringing the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange to mark the 50th anniversary of our listing there. Other upcoming activities will include the Wolfe conference in New York and the European non-DoD Road Show in the fall. 
Before opening the lines for questions, I do want to reiterate John's opening message regarding our exploration of strategic alternatives. We have no additional comments to make on this matter and will not address any questions on the topic during the question-and-answer session. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to the operator to open the lines for your questions.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliabil
componenttext: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliability was an LNG facility. That was put on hold when New Mexico Gas was put up for sale. And in our stipulation, we need to report back to the commission on our plans to address the reliability issue and the LNG. We plan to do that and hope to do that in the context of a total integrated resource plan that we do every 4 years for that company, and work with the commission and other intervenors on what it would look like for the next 4 years. LNG is still a possibility, along with other reliability projects, such as some significant looping of pipelines to address the issue. Whether it's LNG or not LNG or some LNG and some looping, we will have additional investment opportunity similar to the LNG investments that we've talked about earlier.

componenttext: Slightly negative for a period of time in that 0.2%, 0.3%, 0.4%. I think we finally got up to the single digits in 2011. And since then it just steadily climbed, where at 1.8% for Tampa Electric, it's within shouting distance of where it used to be. Our long-term expectations have been kind of in the 1.5%, 1.6% area, but we're outstripping that already. And so we're taking a closer look right now at what the economic indicators are that, are going to shape that going forward. And my expectation would be that it's going to be moving up more like what we've been saying and probably will be getting close to 2%.

componenttext: Andrew, one of the key indicators that most economists look at for new household formation is employment growth. And in Florida and in Tampa with the unemployment rates dropping the way they are, it's a good indicator of new job creation and new household formation and job creation tend to work hand-in-hand.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: And Peoples Gas has the same kind of customer growth pattern, falling off right after its 2008, 2009, and then starting to come back in '11 and inching its way out. So Peoples Gas, on a quarterly basis now has been up in the 2% or above area for 3, 4 quarters. Peoples is a little different because it obviously operates in all areas of the state. But the housing market is really coming back strongly, and we're seeing that in the Peoples growth numbers. So I think what Mark described is appropriate for them as well.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. Definitely positive trends. One last one in terms of the short-term outlook. You're reiterating the guidance range, you didn't repeat all the drivers that you typically do and it's often some small tweaks here and there. One thing I wanted to
componenttext: Sounds good. Definitely positive trends. One last one in terms of the short-term outlook. componenttext: A couple of things to keep in mind. One is that third quarter weather is important as well. And we started out July with a rainy period. It seems like factors are driving us higher rather than lower and that's a good thing.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Natalia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- the typical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with
componenttext:
Thank you, Natalia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- the typical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with the SEC. This presentation is being webcast and our earnings release, statistical summaries and slide for this presentation are available on our website at tecoenergy.com. 
This presentation will be available for replay through the website approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of our presentation and will be available for 30 days. 
In the course of our remarks today, we will be making forward-looking statements about our expectations for 2015 results. There are a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we'll discuss today. For a more complete discussion of these factors, we refer you to the risk factor discussion in our annual report on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2014. 
In the course of today's presentation, we will be using non-GAAP results. There is a reconciliation between these non-GAAP measures in the closest GAAP measure in the appendix to today's presentation. 
The host for our call today is Sandy Callahan, TECO Energy's Chief Financial Officer. Also with us today is John Ramil, TECO Energy's Chief Executive Officer. I'll first turn it over to John for some opening remarks.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning to everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall on the afternoon of July 16, in response to the story that appeared on SparkSpread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that w
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning to everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall on the afternoon of July 16, in response to the story that appeared on SparkSpread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that we have retained Morgan Stanley to advise on this matter. At that time, we stated that the exploration was preliminary in nature, and that we would not update the process or have any additional announcements regarding the matter unless and until we were to enter into a binding definitive agreement with respect to a sale. Today, we have no additional comments to make on this matter and we'll not be addressing this during the question-and-answer session at the end of Sandy's prepared remarks. 
As you saw in our earnings release this morning, due to ongoing negotiations for the sale of TECO Coal and an expected adjustment to the value of that business based on potential sales prices, we're reporting results from continuing operations only this morning. We do not expect the individual operating company results we are reporting today to change as a result of any valuation adjustments that we make in our discontinued operations. 
Now I'll turn it over to Sandy to cover the financial results for continuing operations. Sandy?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share compared with $0.28 last y
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share compared with $0.28 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $61.5 million in 2015 and includes $400,000 of charges related to the New Mexico Gas integration. Results in the quarter reflected close to breakeven results at New Mexico Gas and the full impact of the 16.7 million shares we issued in July last year in connection with that acquisition. That share impact diluted earnings about $0.02 in the quarter. 
For the first 6 months of the year, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $126.3 million, or $0.54 per share, compared with $0.51 last year. Net income from continuing operations for the 6 months was $125.3 million, compared with $110.7 million last year. Both years include costs associated with the New Mexico Gas acquisition, $1 million of integration costs in 2015 and $4.7 million of acquisition costs in 2014. 
Tampa Electric recorded higher net income in the second quarter, reflecting customer growth at a strong 1.8% and hot weather in April and May. We also had the second quarter effect of the base revenue increase that became effective November 1 of last year per Tampa Electric 2013 regulatory stipulation. 
The strong customer growth and better weather resulted in second quarter energy sales that were 6.6% higher than last year. 
AFUDC also increased this quarter, with higher investment balances in the Polk conversion project and other qualified projects. 
Second quarter weather was a real positive. April and May were much hotter than normal, which boosted Tampa Electric Energy sales but hurt Peoples Gas slightly at the tail end of the heating season. Hot weather in April have the air conditioners running early in the season, driving energy sales up, but not to the same magnitude as the cooling degree days were up. With the lower humidity and cooler nights, the high daytime temperatures we saw in April don't generate the same energy sales volumes as they would in the continuously hot and humid summer months when air conditioners seem to run 24/7. 
Peoples Gas has seen quarter-after-quarter of accelerating customer growth. And the second quarter continued this trend with customer growth of 2.2%. Growth was strongest in the Southwest Florida market that has been the most impacted in the economic downturn as well as the Northeast Florida and Jacksonville areas. We saw lower therm sales to residential and commercial customers due to warm April weather at the end of the heating season. But higher therms transported for power-generation customers and higher off-system sales due to increased coal-to-gas switching as well as new generating facilities coming online. 
On the expense side, O&M was lower than last year despite higher employee-related costs. 
The already strong local economy was enhanced this quarter by tourists enjoying the spring weather and the Tampa Bay Lightning's run to the Stanley Cup Finals. Indicative of this, hotel's bed tax collections in the Tampa area were at record levels this quarter, and for the 9 months ended June 2015, were more than 15% higher than they were in 2014. 
While the hockey fans here on the room with me this morning did not like the ultimate outcome, we did appreciate all of the Detroit, Montréal, New York and Chicago fans who visited Tampa this spring. 
New Mexico Gas Company achieved close to breakeven results in the second quarter, and that's the quarter that typically produces a moderate loss. This outcome reflects the benefits of O&M improvement from the integration synergies being realized and customer growth that reached 0.7% in the quarter. 
The other net segment, that we used to refer to as parent other, had a higher net cost in the second quarter compared to last year, as we expected. This was driven by interest expense at the intermediate parent of New Mexico Gas Company and tax expense related to long-term incentive compensation shares that vested below target level. The impact is no longer allocating interest expense to TECO Coal, following its classification as a discontinued operation, was offset by lower interest expense from a refinancing in the second quarter. 
The Florida economy continues to be a good story. Statewide, unemployment at the end of the second quarter was 5.5%, an improvement of a 4% from a year ago. At the same time, the state has added more than 266,000 new jobs over the past year, with the largest number of new jobs occurring in trade, transport and utilities, business services and education and health services. The biggest percentage gain again this quarter occurred in the construction sector, with a 6% employment gain. 
Hillsborough County, Tampa Electric's primary service territory, once again outpaced the state and U.S. level, with unemployment down to 5.2%, almost to full percent below where it was a year ago. Over the past year, the Tampa's St. Petersburg area added 33,000 jobs, with the largest gains in leisure and hospitality, followed by education and health services. 
The unemployment rate in New Mexico was 6.4% in June, an improvement of 0.4% over a year ago, not as dramatic as the improvements in Florida and the U.S, but, of course, the unemployment rate in New Mexico never came close to the peak level that we saw in Florida and nationally. 
Net job growth in New Mexico was 11,000 over the past year, a number impacted by some job losses in the oil and gas industry, as a result of the recent weakness in energy prices. The largest gains in New Mexico's year-over-year job growth came in the education and health services, local government and professional and business services categories. 
Taxable sales, both in Florida and in Hillsborough County, continued to grow with the strong pace that we've seen pretty consistently now over the last 4 years. Reflective of the strong tourist season, if you look at the graph in the appendix, you can see a very strong uptick in April of this year. 
On the housing front, the good story in Florida continues, with more than 5,500 new single-family building permits issued in Tampa Electric service territory over the past 12 months, and existing homes continuing to sell at a very strong pace. 
The June Case-Shiller report shows that selling prices in the Tampa market increased 6.4% year-over-year, which doesn't seem to have dampened sales, and the housing inventory remained at a healthy level of less than 4 months. 
The New Mexico housing market has posted gains as well. In Albuquerque, the state's largest metro area, existing home resales have trended up steadily over the past year. There was a very strong acceleration in the past several months, including a 33% year-over-year increase in June. Selling prices have also trended up and the inventory of homes available for resale is currently about 5 months. You can see all of these trends on the graph in the appendix. 
Our assumptions around guidance, that we've provided previously, remain unchanged. We're maintaining our previously provided guidance for 2015 earnings per share from continuing operations in a range of $1.08 to $1.11, excluding non-GAAP charges or gains. As a regulated utility company, weather is the biggest variable in our outlook, and we assume normal weather for all of our companies for the remainder of the year. That said, if weather is other than normal, our operating companies have typically been very successful responding to weather variation within a reasonably normal range. 
This slide is another graphical reminder that our quarterly earnings pattern will look different with New Mexico Gas Company in our business mix. I've shown a slide previously that illustrated that New Mexico Gas has a very seasonal earnings pattern, with very strong earnings in the cold-weather first and fourth quarters, while the warmer second and third quarters typically produce losses. That's a fairly normal pattern for a gas distribution system with significant residential heating load. So as you can see in the pro forma illustration here, we would expect to see quarterly results meaningfully higher in the first and fourth quarters and somewhat lower in the second and third quarters than they've been in the past. That actually results in less quarterly variation through the year than we've seen in the past, as the New Mexico and Florida earnings patterns are quite complementary. 
Biggest completion of our Polk conversion project is a very important component of our 2017 outlook. I'll again provide a brief status on the construction activities you've seen here. In short, the project is on schedule and it's on budget. This is proven conventional technology and the project scope is smaller than the Bayside conversion project that we successfully completed in the 2003, 2004 time frame. 
This picture shows the progress we're making installing the heat recovery steam generators. This second picture gives you some idea of the size and scope of this $700-million project. You can see the fourth combustion turbine, 2 on either side of the steam turbine island that's located in the center of the picture. 
We will complete our reporting of second quarter results on or before August 7, when we will report full GAAP results including discontinued operations. 
Next Thursday, we will be ringing the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange to mark the 50th anniversary of our listing there. Other upcoming activities will include the Wolfe Conference in New York and the European non-deal roadshow in the fall. 
Before opening the lines for questions, I do want to reiterate John's opening message regarding our exploration of strategic alternatives. We have no additional comments to make on this matter and will not address any questions on the topic during the question-and-answer session. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to the operator to open the lines for your questions.

componenttextpreview: Okay. My last question, John, on New Mexico. Just wanted to get your read or flavor on the regulatory environment there. I'm sure you're aware, the commission has come out and made changes for the forward test year calculations,  just -- were you surprise
componenttext: Okay. My last question, John, on New Mexico. Just wanted to get your read or flavor on the regulatory environment there. I'm sure you're aware, the commission has come out and made changes for the forward test year calculations,  just -- were you surprised by that or how are you looking at the New Mexico regulatory environment today versus the time of the acquisition?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're looking at it in similar fashion. We have been owners of the company for several months now and feel good about the relationship we have had with the regulators over that period of time. It's been very constructive. We were surprised by the order. A
componenttext: We're looking at it in similar fashion. We have been owners of the company for several months now and feel good about the relationship we have had with the regulators over that period of time. It's been very constructive. We were surprised by the order. And as you know, it was appealed to the Mexico Supreme Court. It now appears that the commission has reconsidered that and we'd like to have it back. So we're optimistic that the final rules will be similar to the original intent. And that was that forecasted test year can begin 13 months from an application.

componenttext: Julien, as we've talked about before, we've been following that activity very closely. It's taken shape. It's got a lot of regulatory support. headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliabil
componenttext: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliability was an LNG facility. That was put on hold when New Mexico Gas was put up for sale. And in our stipulation, we need to report back to the commission on our plans to address reliability issue and the LNG. We plan to do that and hope to do that in the context of a total integrated resource plan that we do every 4 years for that company and work with the commission and other intervenors on what it would look like for the next 4 years. LNG is still a possibility, along with other reliability projects, such as some significant looping of pipelines to address the issue. Whether it's LNG or not LNG or some LNG and some looping, we will have additional investment opportunity similar to the LNG investment that we talked about earlier.

componenttext: First of all, the IRP filing is next spring. I don't remember if it's April or March, but in the next spring time period. So we're -- our team's working towards that. The original owners were spending about $30 million a year in capital. Our stipulation, we agreed to spend at least that much. But if you look at our plans, we expect to spend quite a bit more than that, kind of our base going in looking at it, Dan, was about a 4% a year average growth in rate base. But it probably will be more than that as we -- as refined our thinking and are working with the team there more, including some additional investments for the reliability discussion we had earlier.

componenttext: Slightly negative for a period of time and then 0.2%, 0.3%, 0.4%. I think we finally got up to the single digits in 2011. And since then it just steadily climbed, where at 1.8% for Tampa Electric, it's within shouting distance of where it used to be. Our long-term expectations have been kind of in the 1.5%, 1.6% area, but we're outstripping that already. And so we are taking a close look right now at what the economic indicators are, that are going to shape that going forward. And my expectation would be that it's going to be moving up more like what we've been seeing and probably we'll be getting close to 2%.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Natalia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- statistical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with
componenttext:
Thank you, Natalia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Second Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with the utility -- statistical pages, were released earlier this morning and filed with the SEC. This presentation is being webcast and our earnings release, statistical summaries and slides for this presentation are available on our website at tecoenergy.com. 
This presentation will be available for replay through the website approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of our presentation and will be available for 30 days. 
In the course of our remarks today, we will be making forward-looking statements about our expectations for 2015 results. There are a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we'll discuss today. For a more complete discussion of these factors, we refer you to the risk factor discussion in our annual report on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2014. 
In the course of today's presentation, we will be using non-GAAP results. There is a reconciliation between these non-GAAP measures and the closest GAAP measure in the appendix to today's presentation. 
The host for our call today is Sandy Callahan, TECO Energy's Chief Financial Officer. Also with us today is John Ramil, TECO Energy's Chief Executive Officer. I'll first turn it over to John for some opening remarks.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning to everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall, on the afternoon of July 16, in response to a story that appeared in SparkSpread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that we
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning to everybody, and thank you for joining us today. As you recall, on the afternoon of July 16, in response to a story that appeared in SparkSpread, we disclosed that TECO Energy is exploring strategic alternatives and that we had retained Morgan Stanley to advise on this matter. At that time, we stated that the exploration was preliminary in nature, and that we would not update the process or have any additional announcements regarding the matter unless and until we were to enter into a binding definitive agreement with respect to a sale. Today, we have no additional comments to make on this matter and will not be addressing this during the question-and-answer session at the end of Sandy's prepared remarks. 
As you saw in our earnings release this morning, due to ongoing negotiations for the sale of TECO Coal and an expected adjustment to the value of that business based on potential sales prices, we're reporting results from continuing operations only this morning. We do not expect the individual operating company results we are reporting today to change as a result of any valuation adjustments that we make in our discontinued operations. 
Now I'll turn it over to Sandy to cover the financial results for continuing operations. Sandy?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share, compared with $0.28 last
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Today's quarterly update will be normal in every way except that it will cover continuing operations only. In the second quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $61.9 million or $0.26 per share, compared with $0.28 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $61.5 million in 2015 and includes $400,000 of charges related to the New Mexico Gas integration. Results in the quarter reflected close to breakeven results at New Mexico Gas and the full impact of the 16.7 million shares we issued in July last year in connection with that acquisition. That share impact diluted earnings about $0.02 in the quarter. 
For the first 6 months of the year, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $126.3 million, or $0.54 per share, compared with $0.51 last year. Net income from continuing operations for the 6 months was $125.3 million, compared with $110.7 million last year. Both years include costs associated with the New Mexico Gas acquisition, $1 million of integration costs in 2015 and $4.7 million of acquisition costs in 2014. 
Tampa Electric recorded higher net income in the second quarter, reflecting customer growth at a strong 1.8% and hot weather in April and May. We also had the second quarter effect of the base revenue increase that became effective November 1 of last year per Tampa Electric's 2013 regulatory stipulation. 
The strong customer growth and better weather resulted in second quarter energy sales that were 6.6% higher than last year. 
AFUDC also increased this quarter, with higher investment balances in the Polk conversion project and other qualified projects. 
Second quarter weather was a real positive. April and May were much hotter than normal, which boosted Tampa Electric's energy sales but hurt Peoples Gas slightly at the tail end of the heating season. Hot weather in April had the air conditioners running early in the season, driving energy sales up, but not to the same magnitude as the cooling degree days were up. With the lower humidity and cooler nights, the high daytime temperatures we saw in April don't generate the same energy sales volumes as they would in the continuously hot and humid summer months, when air conditioners seem to run 24/7. 
Peoples Gas has seen quarter-after-quarter of accelerating customer growth. And the second quarter continued this trend, with customer growth of 2.2%. Growth was strongest in the Southwest Florida market that has been the most impacted in the economic downturn, as well as the Northeast Florida and Jacksonville areas. We saw lower therm sales to residential and commercial customers, due to warm April weather at the end of the heating season. But higher therms transported for power-generation customers and higher off-system sales, due to increased coal-to-gas switching as well as new generating facilities coming online. 
On the expense side, O&M was lower than last year despite higher employee-related costs. 
The already strong local economy was enhanced this quarter by tourists enjoying the spring weather and the Tampa Bay Lightning's run to the Stanley Cup Finals. Indicative of this, hotels bed tax collections in the Tampa area were at record levels this quarter, and for the 9 months ended June 2015, were more than 15% higher than they were in 2014. 
While the hockey fans here in the room with me this morning did not like the ultimate outcome, we did appreciate all of the Detroit, Montréal, New York and Chicago fans who visited Tampa this spring. 
New Mexico Gas Company achieved close to breakeven results in the second quarter, and that's a quarter that typically produces a moderate loss. This outcome reflects the benefits of O&M improvement from the integration synergies being realized and customer growth that reached 0.7% in the quarter. 
The Other net segment, what we used to refer to as Parent Other, had a higher net cost in the second quarter compared to last year, as we expected. This was driven by interest expense at the intermediate parent of New Mexico Gas Company and tax expense related to long-term incentive compensation shares that vested below target level. The impact of no longer allocating interest expense to TECO Coal, following its classification as a discontinued operation, was offset by lower interest expense from a refinancing in the second quarter. 
The Florida economy continues to be a good story. Statewide, unemployment at the end of the second quarter was 5.5%, an improvement of a full percent from a year ago. At the same time, the state has added more than 266,000 new jobs over the past year, with the largest number of new jobs occurring in trade, transport and utilities, business services and education and health services. The biggest percentage gain again this quarter occurred in the construction sector, with a 6% employment gain. 
Hillsborough County, Tampa Electric's primary service territory, once again outpaced the state and U.S. level, with unemployment down to 5.2%, almost a full percent below where it was a year ago. Over the past year, the Tampa St. Petersburg area added 33,000 jobs, with the largest gains in leisure and hospitality, followed by education and health services. 
The unemployment rate in New Mexico was 6.4% in June, an improvement of 0.4% over a year ago, not as dramatic as the improvements in Florida and the U.S., but of course, the unemployment rate in New Mexico never came close to the peak level that we saw in Florida and nationally. 
Net job growth in New Mexico was 11,000 over the past year, a number impacted by some job losses in the oil and gas industry, as a result of the recent weakness in energy prices. The largest gains in New Mexico's year-over-year job growth came in the education and health services, local government and professional and business services categories. 
Taxable sales, both in Florida and in Hillsborough County, continued to grow with the strong pace that we've seen pretty consistently now over the last 4 years. Reflective of the strong tourist season, if you look at the graph in the appendix, you can see a very strong uptick in April of this year. 
On the housing front, the good story in Florida continues, with more than 5,500 new single-family building permits issued in Tampa Electric's service territory over the past 12 months, and existing homes continuing to sell at a very strong pace. 
The June Case-Shiller report showed that selling prices in the Tampa market increased 6.4% year-over-year, which doesn't seem to have dampened sales, and the housing inventory remains at a healthy level of less than 4 months. 
The New Mexico housing market has posted gains as well. In Albuquerque, the state's largest metro area, existing home resales have trended up steadily over the past year. There was a very strong acceleration in the past several months, including a 33% year-over-year increase in June. Selling prices have also trended up and the inventory of homes available for resale is currently about 5 months. You can see all of these trends on the graph in the appendix. 
Our assumptions around guidance that we've provided previously remain unchanged. We're maintaining our previously provided guidance for 2015 earnings per share from continuing operations in a range of $1.08 to $1.11, excluding non-GAAP charges or gains. As a regulated utility company, weather is the biggest variable in our outlook, and we assume normal weather for all of our companies for the remainder of the year. That said, if weather is other than normal, our operating companies have typically been very successful responding to weather variation within a reasonably normal range. 
This slide is another graphical reminder that our quarterly earnings pattern will look different with New Mexico Gas Company in our business mix. I've shown this slide previously that illustrated that New Mexico Gas has a very seasonal earnings pattern, with very strong earnings in the cold-weather first and fourth quarters, while the warmer second and third quarters typically produce losses. That's a fairly normal pattern for a gas distribution system with significant residential heating load. So as you can see in the pro forma illustration here, we would expect to see quarterly results meaningfully higher in the first and fourth quarters and somewhat lower in the second and third quarters than they've been in the past. That actually results in less quarterly variation through the year than we've seen in the past, as the New Mexico and Florida earnings patterns are quite complementary. 
Because completion of our Polk conversion project is a very important component of our 2017 outlook, I'll again provide a brief status on the construction activities you've seen here. In short, the project is on schedule and it's on budget. This is proven conventional technology and the project scope is smaller than the Bayside conversion project that we successfully completed in the 2003, 2004 time frame. 
This picture shows the progress we're making installing the heat recovery steam generators. This second picture gives you some idea of the size and scope of this $700 million project. You can see the 4 combustion turbines, 2 on either side of the steam turbine island that's located in the center of the picture. 
We will complete our reporting of second quarter results on or before August 7, when we will report full GAAP results including discontinued operations. 
Next Thursday, we will be ringing the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange to mark the 50th anniversary of our listing there. Other upcoming activities will include the Wolfe Conference in New York and a European non-deal roadshow in the fall. 
Before opening the lines for questions, I do want to reiterate John's opening message regarding our exploration of strategic alternatives. We have no additional comments to make on this matter and will not address any questions on the topic during the question-and-answer session. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to the operator to open the lines for your questions.

componenttext: Okay. My last question, John, on New Mexico. Just wanted to get your read or flavor on the regulatory environment there. As I'm sure you're aware, the commission has come out and made changes for the forward test year calculations, just -- were you surprised by that or how are you looking at the New Mexico regulatory environment today versus the time of the acquisition?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're looking at it in similar fashion. We have been owners of the company for several months now and feel good about the relationship we have had with the regulators over that period of time. It's been very constructive. We were surprised by the order. A
componenttext: We're looking at it in similar fashion. We have been owners of the company for several months now and feel good about the relationship we have had with the regulators over that period of time. It's been very constructive. We were surprised by the order. And as you know, it was appealed to the Mexico Supreme Court. It now appears that the commission has reconsidered that and would like to have it back. So we're optimistic that the final rules will be similar to the original intent, and that was that a forecasted test year can begin 13 months from an application.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliabil
componenttext: We have in our stipulation that we have to report back to the commission on our plans to enhance reliability of the system, to minimize the probability that an event will occur like it did back in 2011. The kind of primary thought to provide that reliability was an LNG facility. That was put on hold when New Mexico Gas was put up for sale. And in our stipulation, we need to report back to the commission on our plans to address reliability issue and the LNG. We plan to do that and hope to do that in the context of a total integrated resource plan that we do every 4 years for that company and work with the commission and other intervenors on what it would look like for the next 4 years. LNG is still a possibility, along with other reliability projects, such as some significant looping of pipelines to address the issue. Whether it's LNG or not LNG or some LNG and some looping, we will have additional investment opportunity similar to the LNG investment that we talked about earlier.

componenttextpreview: First of all, the IRP filing is next spring. I don't remember if it's April or March, but in the next spring time period. So we're -- our team's working towards that. The original owners were spending about $30 million a year in capital. Our stipulation,
componenttext: First of all, the IRP filing is next spring. I don't remember if it's April or March, but in the next spring time period. So we're -- our team's working towards that. The original owners were spending about $30 million a year in capital. Our stipulation, we agreed to spend at least that much. But if you look at our plans, we expect to spend quite a bit more than that, kind of our base going in looking at it, Dan, was about a 4% a year average growth in rate base. But it probably will be more than that as we -- as we refine our thinking and are working with the team there more, including some additional investments for the reliability discussion we had earlier.

componenttext: Well, at Peoples Gas, Peoples is replacing some of its cast iron bare steel pipe, and that's an ongoing program. And the cost associated with that is recovered through a rider. At New Mexico Gas, their system is relatively new. And there really is not a wider mechanism in place there to do that, but the need is not significant for New Mexico Gas either, because of the relative newness of that system.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Slightly negative.
componenttext: Slightly negative.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Slightly negative for a period of time and then 0.2%, 0.3%, 0.4%. I think we finally got up to the single digits in 2011. And since then, it has just steadily climbed, where at 1.8% for Tampa Electric, it's within shouting distance of where it used to be.
componenttext: Slightly negative for a period of time and then 0.2%, 0.3%, 0.4%. I think we finally got up to the single digits in 2011. And since then, it has just steadily climbed, where at 1.8% for Tampa Electric, it's within shouting distance of where it used to be. Our long-term expectations have been kind of in the 1.5%, 1.6% area, but we're outstripping that already. And so we are taking a close look right now at what the economic indicators are that are going to shape that going forward. And my expectation would be that it's going to be moving up more like what we've been seeing and probably we'll be getting close to 2%.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Andrew, one of the key indicators that most economists look at for new household formation is employment growth. And in Florida, and in Tampa, with the unemployment rates dropping the way they are, it's a good indicator of new job creation. And new househ
componenttext: Andrew, one of the key indicators that most economists look at for new household formation is employment growth. And in Florida, and in Tampa, with the unemployment rates dropping the way they are, it's a good indicator of new job creation. And new household formation and job creation tend to work hand-in-hand.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Peoples Gas has the same kind of customer growth pattern, falling off right after 2008, 2009, and then starting to come back in '11 and inching its way up. So Peoples Gas, on a quarterly basis, now has been up in the 2% or above area for 3, 4 quarters
componenttext: And Peoples Gas has the same kind of customer growth pattern, falling off right after 2008, 2009, and then starting to come back in '11 and inching its way up. So Peoples Gas, on a quarterly basis, now has been up in the 2% or above area for 3, 4 quarters. Peoples is a little different because it obviously operates in all areas of the state. But the housing market is really coming back strongly, and we're seeing that in the Peoples growth numbers. And so I think what Mark described is appropriate for them as well.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Sounds good. Definitely positive trends. One last one in terms of the short-term outlook. You're reiterating the guidance range, you didn't repeat all the drivers that you typically do and there's often some small tweaks here and there. One thing I wanted to ask about was between the weather, and I guess, the Lightning's rally, it seems like you're tracking well ahead of what you expected for the retail energy sales. Does that mean that you're trending toward the high end or potentially even higher of the guidance?

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of things to keep in mind. One is that third quarter weather is important as well. And we started out July with a rainy period. The other is that Tampa Electric is earning very well in its range, and so there's a limitation as to how high that go
componenttext: A couple of things to keep in mind. One is that third quarter weather is important as well. And we started out July with a rainy period. The other is that Tampa Electric is earning very well in its range, and so there's a limitation as to how high that good weather outlook can take us. And so I think the range remains appropriate. It seems like factors are driving us higher rather than lower and that's a good thing.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brandy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the TECO Energy's third quarter results and 2015 outlook conference call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Mark Kane, yo
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brandy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the TECO Energy's third quarter results and 2015 outlook conference call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Mark Kane, you may begin your conference.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandy. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Third Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with utilities -- statistics pages and the earnings release were released earlier this morn
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandy. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Third Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with utilities -- statistics pages and the earnings release were released earlier this morning. This presentation is being webcast and our earnings release, statistical summaries and slides are available on our website at tecoenergy.com. The presentation will be available for replay through the website approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of our presentation and will be available for 30 days. 
In the course of our remarks today, we will be making forward-looking statements about our expectations for 2015 results and preliminary business drivers for 2016. There are a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we'll discuss today. For a more complete discussion of these factors, we refer you to the risk factor discussion on our annual report on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2014, and as updated in subsequent SEC filings. 
In the course of today's presentation, we will be using non-GAAP results. There is a reconciliation between these non-GAAP measures and the closest GAAP measure in the appendix to today's presentation. 
The host for our call today is Sandy Callahan, TECO Energy's Chief Financial Officer. Also with us today is General Mills -- John Ramil, TECO Energy's CEO. 
Now, I'll turn it over to Sandy.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, I'll cover the status of various filings that we've made with Emera for approval of the acquisition, provide the normal quarterly update and confirm our 2015 outlook. The app
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, I'll cover the status of various filings that we've made with Emera for approval of the acquisition, provide the normal quarterly update and confirm our 2015 outlook. The appendix to the presentation contains the usual graph from the Florida and New Mexico economies and reconciliations of non-GAAP results. 
Since we announced the signing of the agreement with Emera in early September, we have been busy working with Emera to make the required filings in a timely manner. We filed with the FETC on October 6 and asked for approval by March. We filed with the New Mexico commission on October 19. The commission assigned a hearing examiner yesterday and we are waiting for a final order on that. Henceforth, scheduled the established payment proceedings. We filed an initial proxy with the SEC on October 6, and subsequently filed our final proxy on October 22, with a record date of October 21. 
We scheduled the special shareholders' meeting to vote on the approval of the merger for December 3. And over the next several weeks, we expect to make the Hart-Scott-Rodino filing and the filing with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. 
In the third quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $77.3 million or $0.33 per share compared with $0.32 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $64.9 million in 2015, and that includes $12.4 million of charges, primarily associated with the pending acquisition by Emera. 
We closed the sale of TECO Coal this quarter, so I'm not including a report on discontinued operations in my quarterly update. There is a report on discontinued operations included in our earnings release. 
For the first 9 months of the year, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $203.6 million or $0.87 per share compared with $0.84 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $190.2 million compared with $179 million last year. In addition to the cost of this year associated with the Emera transaction, both years include costs associated with the New Mexico Gas acquisition, $1.2 million integration cost in 2015 and $5.7 million of acquisition cost in 2014. 
Tampa Electric reported higher net income in the third quarter. Customer growth was a strong 1.8%, while energy sales was slightly lower than last year, reflecting degree days that were fairly normal but rainfall in July and August that was 60% above normal. Base revenues in the quarter benefited from increase that became effective November 1 of last year for the 2013 regulatory stipulation and AFUDC increased this quarter with higher investment balances in the Polk conversion project and other qualified projects. 
Peoples Gas saw another quarter of 2% customer growth, again, with the strongest numbers in the Southwest and Northeast areas of the state. Both customer and economic growth contributed to higher therm sales to retail customers. Therms transported for power generation customers and all system sales were higher also, reflecting more coal to gas switching as well as new generating facilities coming online. 
The economy continues to do very well and it was helped in the first 9 months of the year by a very strong tourist industry that benefited from Chamber of Commerce weather, the hockey final and new international flights at Tampa International Airport. As an indicator of that, hotel bed tax election in the Tampa area set record in the fiscal year ended September 20, 2015, with numbers 13% higher than 2014, which also was a record year. 
New Mexico Gas Company recorded a seasonal loss in the third quarter, always the weakest revenue quarter because of the absence of heating load. Again, this quarter, we saw the positive impact on O&M, both from integration synergies being realized and an overall focus on cost reduction. Customer growth was worth 0.8% in the quarter and to provide some perspective on that, in the first full quarter that we owned the New Mexico Gas, which was the fourth quarter [ph] of last year, customer growth was half that at 0.4%. 
The other net segment, formerly known as Parent Other, adding net cost in the third quarter but was lower compared to last year due to some unfavorable tax items that were in 2014. Results also reflect the interest expense at New Mexico Gas intermediate, the parent of New Mexico Gas Company. And we only had 1 month of that interest in the 2014 period. And finally, the lower interest expense from a refinancing earlier this year more than offset the impact of no longer allocating interest expense to TECO Coal. 
The Florida economy continues to be a good story. Statewide unemployment at the end of the third quarter was 5.2%, down from 5.8% a year ago, and over that period, the state has added more than 236,000 new jobs. [indiscernible] Tampa Electric primary service territory, once again outpaced the state and U.S. levels, with unemployment down to 4.8%, a full percent below where it was a year ago. 
Over the past year, the Tampa state [indiscernible] served area added more than 28,000 jobs. A nice development in the local employment picture is an increase in the number of higher-paying science, technology, engineering and math, or STEM jobs, in the Tampa Bay Area. According to a Bloomberg study, Tampa has more than 64,000 STEM jobs, representing more than 5% of the workforce, and that is the highest number and percentage among Florida's major metropolitan areas. 
Growth in construction-related jobs in Tampa is being driven by record numbers and record value for building permits. In the 2015 fiscal year that just ended, the city of Tampa issued more than 23,000 building permits, single-family, multifamily and commercial, both new construction and modification, with a value of $2.4 billion. Those numbers represent a 20% increase from 2014, which also was a record year. Aggressive economic development efforts has [indiscernible] almost 12,000 new jobs to the area over the past 3 years, including a number of higher-paying professional and high-tech jobs. 
In New Mexico, the unemployment rate never came close to the level we saw in Florida because of the large presence of the oil and gas industry and governmental facilities in the state. Improvement, though, has been lower than what we've experienced in Florida and in September, the unemployment rate ticked up, primarily due to a slowdown in construction employment. 
Net job growth in New Mexico was 6,400 over the past year, a number impacted by some job losses in the oil and gas industry as a result of the recent looseness [ph] in energy prices. The largest gain came in education and health services, leisure and hospitality, and professional and business service categories. The Albuquerque area, which constitutes almost 50% of the state nonforeign payroll, led the state in job creation, adding 6,600 jobs over the year and offsetting net job losses in some of the less probable areas. 
On the housing front, the good story in the Tampa area continues, with more than 5,800 new single-family building permits issued over the past 12 months, and increasing homes continuing to sell at a strong pace. The October Case-Shiller report shows that selling prices in the Tampa market increased 6.1% year-over-year. With a strong pace of resale, the housing inventory remains at a healthy level of less than 4 months. 
In Albuquerque, New Mexico's largest Metro area, existing home resales have trended up steadily over the past year. There was a very strong acceleration in recent months including a 33% year-over-year increase in June, and 26% in September. Selling prices have also trended up in the inventory of homes available for resale or just under 5 months. 
You can see all of these trends on the graph in the appendix. Our assumptions around guidance that we've provided previously remain unchanged. We are maintaining our previously provided guidance for 2015, earnings per share from continuing operations in a range of $1.08 to $1.11 excluding non-GAAP charges or  gain [ph]. We still expect New Mexico Gas to be accretive to our full year earnings but it has been a challenge to overcome the very mild winter weather that started the year. We had great results on the cost side and that is helping to offset the impact of disappointing first quarter weather, but we do need some normal cold winter weather to close that year. 
Looking forward to next year. All indications are that we should continue to see strong customer growth at all 3 of the utilities. We expect the Florida utilities to earn toward the upper end of the expected return on equity ranges shown on the slide. 
Tampa Electric AFUDC earnings will grow next year as the investment in the Polk conversion project reaches its peak. And in addition, a $5 million base revenue increase became effective November 1 of this year as a result of the 2013 settlement agreement. 
All of utilities expect to record higher depreciation expense as a result of continued investment in equipment and facilities to serve customers. And of course, across the board, we will continue to be very focused on holding the lines on cost. 
Our upcoming investor communications schedule includes being at EEI next week where we will participate jointly with Emera and one-on-one meetings and also will be a part of Emera's presentation at 10:30 on Tuesday morning. 
After the Emera acquisition announcement, we've been asked if we would continue to have quarterly conference calls. Because of the timing of EEI next week and our activity there, we decided to have a call this quarter, but future calls will be on an as-needed basis only. 
And now I will turn it over to the operator to open the line for the questions. Thank you.

headline: TECO Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brandy. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Third Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with utilities -- statistical pages and the earnings release were released earlier this mor
componenttext:
Thank you, Brandy. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the TECO Energy Third Quarter 2015 Results Conference Call. Our results from continuing operations, along with utilities -- statistical pages and the earnings release were released earlier this morning. This presentation is being webcast and our earnings release, statistical summaries and slides are available on our website at tecoenergy.com. The presentation will be available for replay through the website approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of our presentation and will be available for 30 days. 
In the course of our remarks today, we will be making forward-looking statements about our expectations for 2015 results and preliminary business drivers for 2016. There are a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we'll discuss today. For a more complete discussion of these factors, we refer you to the risk factor discussion on our annual report on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2014, and as updated in subsequent SEC filings. 
In the course of today's presentation, we will be using non-GAAP results. There is a reconciliation between these non-GAAP measures and the closest GAAP measure in the appendix to today's presentation. 
The host for our call today is Sandy Callahan, TECO Energy's Chief Financial Officer. Also with us today is John Ramil's -- John Ramil, TECO Energy's CEO. 
Now I'll turn it over to Sandy.

We filed an initial proxy with the SEC on October 6, and subsequently filed our final proxy on October 22, with a record date of October 21. 
We scheduled a special shareholder meeting to vote on the approval of the merger for December 3. And over the next several weeks, we expect to make the Hart-Scott-Rodino filing and the filing with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. 
In the third quarter, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $77.3 million or $0.33 per share compared with $0.32 last year. For the first 9 months of the year, non-GAAP results from continuing operations were $203.6 million or $0.87 per share compared with $0.84 last year. Net income from continuing operations was $190.2 million compared with $179 million last year. In addition to the cost this year associated with the Emera transaction, both years include costs associated with the New Mexico Gas acquisition; $1.2 million integration cost in 2015; and $5.7 million of acquisition cost in 2014.

Peoples Gas saw another quarter of 2% customer growth, again with the strongest numbers in the southwest and northeast areas of the state. Both customer and economic growth contributed to higher therm sales to retail customers. Sales to transported power generation customers and off-system sales were higher also, reflecting more coal to gas switching as well as new generating facilities coming online.

And to provide some perspective on that, in the first full quarter that we owned New Mexico Gas, which was the fourth quarter of last year, customer growth was 1/2 that at 0.4%. 
The other net segment, formerly known as parent other, adding net cost in the third quarter that was lower compared to last year due to some unfavorable tax items that were in 2014. Results also reflect the interest expense at New Mexico Gas Intermediate, the parent of New Mexico Gas Company. And we only had 1 month of that interest in the 2014 period. And finally, the lower interest expense from a refinancing earlier this year more than offset the impact of no longer allocating interest expense to TECO Coal. 
The Florida economy continues to be a good story. Statewide unemployment at the end of the third quarter was 5.2%, down from 5.8% a year ago. And over that period, the state has added more than 236,000 new jobs. Hillsborough County, Tampa Electric primary service territory, once again outpaced the state and U.S. levels, with unemployment down to 4.8%, a full percent below where it was 1 year ago.  
Over the past year, the Tampa St. Petersburg area added more than 28,000 jobs. A nice development in the local employment picture is an increase in the number of higher-paying science, technology, engineering and math, or STEM jobs, in the Tampa Bay Area.  According to a Bloomberg study, Tampa has more than 64,000 STEM jobs, representing more than 5% of the workforce, and that is the highest number and percentage among Florida's major metropolitan areas.

Aggressive economic development efforts has brought almost 12,000 new jobs to the area over the past 3 years, including a number of higher-paying professional and high-tech jobs.

Improvement, though, has been slower than what we've experienced in Florida. And in September, the unemployment rate ticked up, primarily due to a slowdown in construction employment.
